Riverside Drive (thorough fare at the right upon which the buildings shown, front), north from a point on a line with West 163rd Street (extreme right) showing a more or less general view of the Washington Heights building outline on the westerly margin of Manhattan. Two groups of structures of importance are: the low buildings of the New York Institution for the Deaf (right, extending from West 163rd to 165th Streets) and the Columbia University - Presbyterian Hospital Medical Center which are just north of the aforementioned. View 2 of this set, being from a vantage point to the north, emphasizes the latter. The foreground area is today (1938), included officially in Fort Washington Park, that marginal garden spot under the new George Washington Bridge (in the left background).

September 24, 1931.

P. L. Sperr.

September 24, 1931.

Riverside Drive, at the N. E. corner of W. 163rd Street, showing the grounds of the New York School for the Deaf. These are being cleared of the former institution buildings; though one still remains. In the background are the massive units of the Columbia Medical Center.

View 1: August 21, 1939
Views 2,3: May 18, 1940

P. L. Sperr

Riverside Drive, north from W. 163rd Street. Buildings shown form the Columbia Medical Center. On the right are the main units at Broadway. The Presbyterian Hospital School of Nursing is in the center. To the left is the Neurological Institute.

View 3 is taken on that portion of the Drive, the Boulevard Lafayette and includes at its right one of the old buildings that formerly housed the New York Institution for the Deaf. This escarpment appears in the midground of the preceding photos.
May 18, 1940
Views 1,2,3
P. L. Sperr
